title: What are the best computer science certifications to get for high school students? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Computer Science certification”. I’m assuming you’re discussing professional certifications. No. Computer Science isn’t a particular piece of software, nor is it a vocation. It’s a mathematical science, an academic field of study that studies computation. If somebody is trying to tell you they can give you a “certification” in Computer Science, I advise ignoring it. People like me won’t take you seriously with a “certification” as a basis of your supposed expertise. An expert is my field is somebody for instance that contributes to the scientific literature in this field, and has dedicated their work in studying it for years. I do not like speaking in the terms of who is and isn’t an “expert”, but there is an important distinction to be made between what an actual contributor to CS is, versus somebody treating the field like it’s some static entity that is unchanging and doesn’t contribute to it and only applies it. Computer Science is something you earn a university degree in. If somebody is trying to promise you a x-month certification in a scientific field, it’s not a good idea to buy into it. If they are offering more, like a set of courses you can take or a workshop, and it is being run by actual computer scientists, then we might be talking about something out. If I were to tell you that you could get a “certification” in Physics, you’d probably find that funny. It’s no different here. A high school student has enough stuff going on, if they are genuinely curious about CS, you can always just learn more CS. If you’re interested in software development (something different), then you can pursue perhaps (on the topic of certifications) certifications for specific industry-level pieces of software. I really don’t think the average high-schooler is prepared for anything like that (it takes time to learn these things), so be warned.

None. Certifications are worthless outside of very narrow areas (like Infiniband version 6 configuration or something.) They won’t impress a college, an employer, your peers, or anyone else. Worse, they’ll give you a false sense of achievement or competence at a time when you can be doing real learning.
